relationships.notes: Shares intimate meals with Jesus before handing him over, fulfilling the predicted betrayal through a kiss and departure into the night.
Negotiates payment with the chief priests and temple officers, seeking an opportune moment to hand Jesus over away from the crowd.
His vacated place among the Twelve is filled by Matthias after Peter recounts Judas’s death and cites Psalms about his office.

traits.role_among_twelve: Listed among the Twelve and later singled out as the one who hands Jesus over to the authorities.
traits.betrayal_motive: Goes to the chief priests to betray Jesus in exchange for money; the narrative does not probe his inner motivations.
traits.relationship_to_jesus: Appears as an insider who shares meals and intimate space with Jesus before becoming the instrument of his arrest.
traits.characterization: Portrayed with minimal psychological detail, functioning mainly as a narrative agent of betrayal and fulfillment of Jesus’s predictions.
traits.death_account: Mark does not narrate his death, leaving his ultimate fate unmentioned.

traits.role_among_twelve: Named among the Twelve and explicitly identified as the one who betrays Jesus.
traits.betrayal_motive: Initiates contact with the chief priests asking what they will give him, accepting thirty pieces of silver.
traits.relationship_to_jesus: Shares the last meal with Jesus, who predicts that one of those eating with him will betray him.
traits.remorse_and_death: After seeing Jesus condemned, he feels remorse, returns the silver, confesses that he has betrayed innocent blood, and then hangs himself.
traits.field_of_blood_tradition: The priests use the returned money to buy the potter’s field, which becomes known as the Field of Blood, framed as fulfillment of prophetic scripture.

traits.role_among_twelve: Listed among the Twelve with the note that he became a traitor.
traits.betrayal_motive: Luke attributes his action to Satan entering into him before he consults with the chief priests and officers about how to betray Jesus.
traits.relationship_to_jesus: Leads the crowd to Jesus on the Mount of Olives and marks him out with a kiss, which Jesus pointedly questions.
traits.characterization: His betrayal is embedded in a larger motif of satanic opposition to Jesus’s mission rather than in explicit financial motives.
traits.death_account: Luke’s Gospel alludes only to his betrayal and does not narrate his death; that is deferred to Acts.

traits.role_among_twelve: Introduced as one of the Twelve, repeatedly identified as the one who would betray Jesus.
traits.betrayal_motive: Depicted as keeper of the common purse and labeled a thief who steals from it; Satan enters him at the meal when he receives the morsel from Jesus.
traits.relationship_to_jesus: Shares close table fellowship but is set in contrast to the beloved disciple; Jesus hands him the dipped morsel as a sign to the inner circle.
traits.theological_role: Functions as a dark counterpart within the disciple group, exemplifying unbelief and satanic influence inside the community.
traits.narrative_exit: After Satan enters him, he departs into the night, and his later death is not narrated; the emphasis falls on his departure and betrayal.

traits.role_among_twelve: Referred to as one of the number of the apostles whose place must be taken by another.
traits.betrayal_motive: His deed is described as a lawless act that led to Jesus’s arrest, with emphasis on scriptural fulfillment rather than psychological motivation.
traits.death_account: Said to have acquired a field with the reward of his wickedness and to have fallen headlong so that his body burst open and his bowels gushed out.
traits.field_of_blood_tradition: The gruesome death and the naming of the field as Akeldama (Field of Blood) are tied to local knowledge and interpreted through Psalms as prophecy.
traits.theological_role: Serves as a negative figure whose vacated office is filled by Matthias, underscoring divine oversight of the apostolic witness.
